messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 46 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Efficient algorithms for certifying lower bounds on the discrepancy of random matrices

Paper Abstract: Abstract We initiate the study of the algorithmic problem of certifying lower bounds on the discrepancy of random matrices: given an input matrix A∈ℝm×n𝐴superscriptℝ𝑚𝑛A\in\mathbb{R}^{m\times n}, output a value that is a lower bound on 𝖽𝗂𝗌𝖼(A)=minx∈{±1}n∥Ax∥∞\mathsf{disc}(A)=\min_{x\in\{\pm 1\}^{n}}\left\lVert Ax\right\rVert_{\infty} for every A𝐴A, but is close to the typical value of 𝖽𝗂𝗌𝖼​(A)𝖽𝗂𝗌𝖼𝐴\mathsf{disc}(A) with high probability over the choice of a random A𝐴A. This problem is important because of its connections to conjecturally-hard average-case problems such as negatively-spiked PCA [BKW20], the number-balancing problem [GK21] and refuting random constraint satisfaction problems [RRS17]. We give the first polynomial-time algorithms with non-trivial guarantees for two main settings. First, when the entries of A𝐴A are i.i.d. standard Gaussians, it is known that 𝖽𝗂𝗌𝖼​(A)=Θ​(n​2−n/m)𝖽𝗂𝗌𝖼𝐴Θ𝑛superscript2𝑛𝑚\mathsf{disc}(A)=\Theta(\sqrt{n}2^{-n/m}) with high probability [CV14, APZ19, TMR20] and that super-constant levels of the Sum-of-Squares SDP hierarchy fail to certify anything better than 𝖽𝗂𝗌𝖼​(A)≥0𝖽𝗂𝗌𝖼𝐴0\mathsf{disc}(A)\geq 0 when m<n−o​(n)𝑚𝑛𝑜𝑛m<n-o(n) [GJJ+20]. In contrast, our algorithm certifies that 𝖽𝗂𝗌𝖼​(A)≥exp⁡(−O​(n2/m))𝖽𝗂𝗌𝖼𝐴𝑂superscript𝑛2𝑚\mathsf{disc}(A)\geq\exp(-O(n^{2}/m)) with high probability. As an application, this formally refutes a conjecture of Bandeira, Kunisky, and Wein [BKW20] on the computational hardness of the detection problem in the negatively-spiked Wishart model. Second, we consider the integer partitioning problem: given n𝑛n uniformly random b𝑏b-bit integers a1,…,ansubscript𝑎1…subscript𝑎𝑛a_{1},\ldots,a_{n}, certify the non-existence of a perfect partition, i.e. certify that 𝖽𝗂𝗌𝖼​(A)≥1𝖽𝗂𝗌𝖼𝐴1\mathsf{disc}(A)\geq 1 for A=(a1,…,an)𝐴subscript𝑎1…subscript𝑎𝑛A=(a_{1},\ldots,a_{n}). Under the scaling b=α​n𝑏𝛼𝑛b=\alpha n, it is known that the probability of the existence of a perfect partition undergoes a phase transition from 1 to 0 at α=1𝛼1\alpha=1 [BCP01]; our algorithm certifies the non-existence of perfect partitions for some α=O​(n)𝛼𝑂𝑛\alpha=O(n). We also give efficient non-deterministic algorithms with significantly improved guarantees, raising the possibility that the landscape of these certification problems closely resembles that of e.g. the problem of refuting random 3SAT formulas in the unsatisfiable regime. Our algorithms involve a reduction to the Shortest Vector Problem and employ the Lenstra-Lenstra-Lovász algorithm.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 46 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 46"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Public-key cryptography from different assumptions",
        "Proof of the contiguity conjecture and lognormal limit for the symmetric perceptron",
        "The discrepancy of random rectangular matrices",
        "Storage capacity in symmetric binary perceptrons",
        "Lattice problems in NP cap conp",
        "Algorithmic aspects of combinatorial discrepancy",
        "Spectral planting and the hardness of refuting cuts, colorability, and communities in random graphs",
        "Proof of the local REM conjecture for number partitioning. I: constant energy scales",
        "Proof of the local REM conjecture for number partitioning. II. growing energy scales",
        "Phase transition and finite-size scaling for the integer partitioning problem",
        "Number partitioning as a random energy model",
        "Computational hardness of certifying bounds on constrained PCA problems",
        "Universality in the level statistics of disordered systems",
        "Analysis of the karmarkar-karp differencing algorithm",
        "A near-optimal algorithm for approximating the john ellipsoid",
        "The discrepancy method - randomness and complexity",
        "Tight hardness results for minimizing discrepancy",
        "Balancing gaussian vectors",
        "A panorama of discrepancy theory, volume 2107",
        "Integer feasibility of random polytopes: random integer programs",
        "Complexity theoretic limitations on learning halfspaces",
        "Non-gaussian component analysis via lattice basis reduction",
        "Witnesses for non-satisfiability of dense random 3cnf formulas",
        "Semialgebraic proofs and efficient algorithm design",
        "The overlap gap property: A topological barrier to optimizing over random structures",
        "Computers and Intractability: A Guide to the Theory of NP-Completeness",
        "Sum-of-squares lower bounds for sherrington-kirkpatrick via planted affine planes",
        "Algorithmic obstructions in the random number partitioning problem",
        "Algorithms and barriers in the symmetric binary perceptron model",
        "Inference in high-dimensional linear regression via lattice basis reduction and integer relation detection",
        "Phase transitions and annealed theories: Number partitioning as a case study",
        "Balancing covariates in randomized experiments using the gram-schmidt walk",
        "Nearly random designs with greatly improved balance",
        "The differencing method of set partitioning",
        "Sum of squares lower bounds for refuting any CSP",
        "A complete anytime algorithm for number partitioning",
        "Factoring polynomials with rational coefficients",
        "Geometric discrepancy: An illustrated guide, volume 18",
        "Phase transition in the number partitioning problem",
        "Random costs in combinatorial optimization",
        "Discrepancy in random hypergraph models",
        "Frozen 1-rsb structure of the symmetric ising perceptron",
        "Strongly refuting random csps below the spectral threshold",
        "On the cryptographic hardness of learning single periodic neurons",
        "Balancing gaussian vectors in high dimension",
        "Lattice-based methods surpass sum-of-squares in clustering"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 46 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Efficient algorithms for certifying lower bounds on the discrepancy of random matrices, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
